title: 114_hr5919
content: The Act may be cited as the "Preserving and Reforming SSDI (PAR-SSDI) Act of 2016" and includes consideration of vocational factors in disability determinations. The "Preserving and Reforming SSDI (PAR-SSDI) Act of 2016" amends the Social Security Act to exclude language proficiency and vocational background from disability determinations. The Commissioner of Social Security will update vocational and educational factors for disability determinations every 5 years. The amendments apply to disability insurance benefits applications filed after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Disqualification for receiving disability insurance benefits while also receiving unemployment compensation. Section 223(d)(4) of the Social Security Act is amended to include that individuals receiving unemployment compensation are deemed to have engaged in substantial gainful activity for that month. This includes various types of unemployment compensation as defined by the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act and trade adjustment assistance under the Trade Act of 1974. The Social Security Act is amended to include that individuals receiving unemployment compensation are deemed to have rendered services in a month. This includes various types of unemployment compensation as defined by the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act and trade adjustment assistance under the Trade Act of 1974. The Commissioner of Social Security will use electronic data for implementing amendments related to data matching. These amendments will apply to individuals applying for disability insurance benefits on or after January 1, 2017. SEC. 4. ELIGIBILITY FOR MEDICARE. Section 226(b)(2) of the Social Security Act is amended to extend the time period from 24 to 60 calendar months for various provisions related to entitlement and status. The Social Security Act is amended to extend the time period from 24 to 60 months for disability insurance benefits applications filed after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. INCLUSION OF UNEARNED INCOME IN DETERMINATION OF SUBSTANTIAL GAINFUL ACTIVITY. The Social Security Act is amended to include unearned income in determining substantial gainful activity. If an individual's unearned income exceeds the monthly limit, they will be considered to have engaged in substantial gainful activity. This amendment will apply to insurance benefits paid after one year from the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. MEDICAL EVIDENCE IN DISABILITY DETERMINATIONS. Section 223(d)(5) of the Social Security Act is amended to require individuals to submit all relevant medical evidence without redaction. The Commissioner of Social Security cannot consider any medical evidence that is not submitted in its entirety. The individual or their representative must certify at a hearing that all relevant medical evidence has been submitted without redaction. "Relevant medical evidence" includes any medical evidence related to the individual's claimed impairments that the Commissioner of Social Security should consider. This does not include any communication between the individual and their attorney that is privileged. The attorney-client privilege and work product doctrine do not prevent the disclosure of medical evidence or opinions relevant to determining benefits. Violating this rule can result in penalties under sections 208 and 1129, including suspension or disqualification from representing individuals before the Social Security Administration. Beginning 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Commissioner of Social Security will not consider medical evidence from a consultative exam unless accompanied by a signed Medical Consultant Acknowledgment Form. The Medical Consultant Acknowledgment Form is a document developed by the Commissioner of Social Security to provide information on how medical evidence is used in disability determinations. It must be signed by the health care provider who conducted the exam and will be required starting 1 year after the enactment of this Act. The Medical Consultant Acknowledgment Form provides instructions on completing a residual functional capacity form and outlines the legal and ethical obligations of health care providers supplying medical evidence for disability determinations, including potential penalties for fraud. Any individual who forges a signature on a Medical Consultant Acknowledgment Form submitted to the Commissioner of Social Security may face civil and criminal penalties under the Social Security Act. The amendments apply to disability insurance benefit applications filed after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 7. Change in index for calculating Social Security cost-of-living adjustments. Section 215(i)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to define the term 'Consumer Price Index' as the Chained Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (C-CPI-U). This amendment also applies to pre-1979 law. The amendment defines the term 'Consumer Price Index' as the Chained Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (C-CPI-U). It also includes a conforming change to the Social Security Act. The effective date for these amendments is at least 3 years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 8. THIRD-PARTY INCOME VERIFICATION. Section 223(i) of the Social Security Act is amended to include a requirement for an independent estimate of monthly income for individuals under disability review. The Commissioner of Social Security must provide necessary information to a qualified contractor for this purpose. The Commissioner of Social Security must enter into qualified income verification contracts within 60 days of enactment. These contracts involve providing income estimates for specified individuals and prohibiting contact with them or their employers. The Commissioner of Social Security can enter into qualified income verification contracts within 60 days of enactment. These contracts involve providing income estimates for specified individuals and prohibiting contact with them or their employers. A qualified social security income verification contractor can receive identifying information from the Secretary. The United States is not liable for any actions of contractors under these contracts. The Commissioner of Social Security can enter into qualified income verification contracts within 60 days of enactment. These contracts involve providing income estimates for specified individuals and prohibiting contact with them or their employers. If an independent estimate shows inaccurate reporting of monthly income by an individual receiving disability benefits, the Commissioner will investigate to determine if the income reflects the ability to work.
